preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-7.0 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Broccoli seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.5 inches deep with 18 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Broccoli deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Broccoli weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Broccoli approximately 65 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Broccoli at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

Choose location with partial shade receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily

Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant broccoli and peppers in rows, about 18 inches apart. Leave a 3-foot gap between the two rows for easy access.
Sow spinach seeds densely, about 4 inches apart, in a separate bed or section of the main garden area. This will allow for easy harvesting and minimize competition from other plants.

general_tips: Start your seeds indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date to give them a head start on the growing season.
Choose varieties of broccoli that mature quickly (around 50-60 days) to ensure you get a harvest before the first frost.

Peppers are warm-season crops and prefer well-draining soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0. Make sure your garden bed has good drainage and add organic matter like compost or manure to improve soil structure.
Spinach is a cool-season crop that prefers partial shade and consistent moisture. Plant it in early spring as soon as the soil can be worked, or in late summer for a fall harvest.
In Moncton's cold climate, it's essential to provide protection from frost using row covers or other methods when planting broccoli and spinach.
Broccoli and peppers require full sun (at least 6 hours of direct sunlight) to produce well. Make sure your garden bed receives sufficient sunlight and consider using a trellis for support if needed.
